revisions.rev:
{{Globalize|date=September 2021|2=the [[Anglosphere]] particularly the United States}}{{distinguish|Discrimination against intersex people}} {{short description|Prejudicial treatment of people who do not identify as male or female}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2019}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} {{Transgender sidebar}} [[Discrimination]] or prejudice against [[non-binary]] people, people who do not [[Gender identity|identify]] as male or female, may occur in social, legal, or medical contexts. This is sometimes known as enbyphobia. Both [[cisgender]] and [[transgender]] people (men and women), including members of the [[lesbian]], [[gay]], and [[bisexual]] communities, can display such prejudice.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/kelsie-brynn-jones/when-being-trans-is-not-t_b_6340728.html | title=When Being Trans Is Not Trans Enough | work=Huffington Post | date=February 2, 2016 | access-date=June 4, 2016 | author=Kelsie Brynn Jones}}</ref>{{unreliable source|sure=y|reason=HuffPo contributor blog|date=October 2019}}
==Social discrimination== In terms of the [[binary gender]] system, genderqueerness may be considered unintelligible and abjected.<ref name="ftmborderlands">Hale, J.C. (1998) "...[O]ur embodiments and our subjectivities are abjected from social ontology: we cannot fit ourselves into extant categories without denying, eliding, erasing, or otherwise abjecting personally significant aspects of ourselves ... When we choose to live with and in our dislocatedness, fractured from social ontology, we choose to forgo intelligibility: lost in language and in social life, we become virtually unintelligible, even to ourselves..." from ''Consuming the Living, Dis(Re)Membering the Dead in the Butch/FtM Borderlands'' in the ''Gay and Lesbian Quarterly'' 4:311, 336 (1998). Retrieved on April 7, 2007.</ref>
[[Discrimination|Social discrimination]] in the context of discrimination against non-binary and gender non-conforming people includes hate-motivated violence and excusing of such.{{cn|date=December 2020}} According to a 2016 study from ''[[Journal of Sex Research|The Journal of Sex Research]],'' one of the most common themes of discrimination for genderqueer people is the incorrect use of preferred gender pronouns. The study labeled this as 'nonaffirmation', and it occurs when others do not affirm one's sense of gender identity. Participants within this study also reported experiencing [[gender policing]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Nadal|first1=Kevin L.|last2=Whitman|first2=Chassitty N.|last3=Davis|first3=Lindsey S.|last4=Erazo|first4=Tanya|last5=Davidoff|first5=Kristin C.|date=2016-03-11|title=Microaggressions Toward Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, and Genderqueer People: A Review of the Literature|journal=The Journal of Sex Research|language=en|volume=53|issue=4–5|pages=488–508|doi=10.1080/00224499.2016.1142495|pmid=26966779|s2cid=23205208|issn=0022-4499}}</ref> An article from the book ''Violence and Gender'', states that this experienced violence and discrimination leads to high levels of stress. This article stated that non-binary participants are less likely to experience hate speech (24.4% vs. 50%) compared to trans men and equally as likely (24.4% vs. 24.4%) as trans women, yet genderqueer/nonbinary participants, along with trans women, are more likely than trans men individuals to be concerned about the safety of themselves and others.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Veldhuis|first1=Cindy B.|last2=Drabble|first2=Laurie|last3=Riggle|first3=Ellen D.B.|last4=Wootton|first4=Angie R.|last5=Hughes|first5=Tonda L.|date=March 2018|title="I Fear for My Safety, but Want to Show Bravery for Others": Violence and Discrimination Concerns Among Transgender and Gender-Nonconforming Individuals After the 2016 Presidential Election|journal=Violence and Gender|volume=5|issue=1|pages=26–36|doi=10.1089/vio.2017.0032|issn=2326-7836|doi-access=free}}</ref>
===United States=== Of the approximately 6,450 transgender and gender-nonconforming respondents to the National Transgender Discrimination Survey (NTDS), conducted by the [[National Center for Transgender Equality]] and National Gay and Lesbian Task Force in 2008–2009,<ref name="ncte-ntds">{{cite web|title=National Transgender Discrimination Survey|url=https://transequality.org/sites/default/files/docs/resources/NTDS_Report.pdf|website=National Center for Transgender Equality|access-date=April 26, 2017}}</ref>{{rp|12–15, 50}} 864 (13%) chose the write-in option for gender identity, "A gender not listed here (please specify)".<ref name="ncte-ntds"/>{{rp|16}} (The other options were "Male/man", "Female/women", and "Part time as one gender, part time as another".)<ref name="ncte-ntds"/>{{rp|16}} Responses from these participants were analysed in the 2011 journal article "A Gender Not Listed Here: Genderqueers, Gender Rebels, and Otherwise in the National Transgender Discrimination Survey".<ref name="Harrison2011">{{cite journal|author1=Jack Harrison|author2=Jaime Grant|author3=Jody L. Herman|year=2011–2012|title=A Gender Not Listed Here: Genderqueers, Gender Rebels, and Otherwise in the National Transgender Discrimination Survey|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/downloads/release_materials/agendernotlistedhere.pdf|journal=LGBTQ Policy Journal|volume=2|access-date=March 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725182217/http://www.thetaskforce.org/downloads/release_materials/agendernotlistedhere.pdf|archive-date=July 25, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> The "a gender not listed here" (Q3GNL) individuals reported higher rates of physical (32% vs. 25%) and sexual (15% vs 9%) assault due to bias than other NTDS respondents.<ref name="Harrison2011"/>{{rp|23}}
==Workplace discrimination== {{Globalize|section|USA|2name=the United States|date=October 2018}}
===United States===
According to the NTDS, almost all non-binary persons had experienced discrimination in the workplace. Their findings show that being out as a non-binary person negatively affects that person's employment outcomes. Though non-binary persons have higher unemployment rates than those who identify with a specified gender, masculine non-binary persons who still appear male, or are not "passing as female" generally have a harder time in the work environment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://scholarworks.umass.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1331&context=masters_theses_2|title=Gender Inequality: Nonbinary Transgender People in the Workplace|last=Davidson|first=Skylar|date=April 26, 2017|website=umass.edu}}</ref> 19% of Q3GNL respondents to the NTDS reported job loss due to anti-transgender bias, a smaller proportion than for other respondents (27%).<ref name="transgenderlawcenter" />{{rp|8}}
Not only does discrimination against transgender people in the workplace affect transgender employees, but it also affects the entire workplace team, distracting the victim and the perpetrator from the job itself.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Barclay |first1=J.M. |last2=Scott |first2=L.J. |title=Transsexuals and workplace diversity |journal=Personnel Review |date=July 2006 |volume=35 |issue=4 |pages=487–502 |doi=10.1108/00483480610670625}}</ref> Transgender individuals in the U.S. often face workplace discrimination like conflicts related to their bathroom usage, backlash over transitioning genders and being misgendered by coworkers. The Center of American Progress in 2012 also found that there is also a substantial amount of public ignorance towards transgender communities, in comparison to LGB community peers. Because of that, negative psychological consequences occur as a result like mental [[health disparities]], higher rates in attempted suicide, and paranoid thinking in public spaces.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Haas |first1=Ann P. |last2=Eliason |first2=Mickey |last3=Mays |first3=Vickie M. |last4=Mathy |first4=Robin M. |last5=Cochran |first5=Susan D. |last6=D'Augelli |first6=Anthony R. |last7=Silverman |first7=Morton M. |last8=Fisher |first8=Prudence W. |last9=Hughes |first9=Tonda |last10=Rosario |first10=Margaret |last11=Russell |first11=Stephen T. |last12=Malley |first12=Effie |last13=Reed |first13=Jerry |last14=Litts |first14=David A. |last15=Haller |first15=Ellen |last16=Sell |first16=Randall L. |last17=Remafedi |first17=Gary |last18=Bradford |first18=Judith |last19=Beautrais |first19=Annette L. |last20=Brown |first20=Gregory K. |last21=Diamond |first21=Gary M. |last22=Friedman |first22=Mark S. |last23=Garofalo |first23=Robert |last24=Turner |first24=Mason S. |last25=Hollibaugh |first25=Amber |last26=Clayton |first26=Paula J. |title=Suicide and Suicide Risk in Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Transgender Populations: Review and Recommendations |journal=Journal of Homosexuality |date=30 December 2010 |volume=58 |issue=1 |pages=10–51 |doi=10.1080/00918369.2011.534038 |doi-access=free |pmid=21213174 |pmc=3662085}}</ref>
==Health discrimination==
===United States=== A survey conducted among rural U.S. LGBT populations suggested that transgender and non-binary patients were three times more likely to find health care providers that have other LGBT patients. They were also three times more likely to drive over an hour out of the way to visit their health care provider due "to the fact that in the last year, one in ten had visited an LGBT-specific health care clinic, which are often located in urban areas."<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Whitehead|first1=J.|last2=Shaver|first2=John|last3=Stephenson|first3=Rob|date=January 5, 2016|title=Outness, Stigma, and Primary Health Care Utilization among Rural LGBT Populations|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=11|issue=1|pages=e0146139|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0146139|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4701471|pmid=26731405|bibcode=2016PLoSO..1146139W|doi-access=free}}</ref>
20.4% of transgender and gender-nonconforming respondents to the NTDS reported having experienced discrimination when trying to access doctors and hospitals, 11.9% when attempting to access emergency rooms, and 4.6% when attempting to access the service of an ambulance.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Kattari|first1=Shanna K.|last2=Walls|first2=N. Eugene|last3=Whitfield|first3=Darren L.|last4=Langenderfer-Magruder|first4=Lisa|date=2015-04-03|title=Racial and Ethnic Differences in Experiences of Discrimination in Accessing Health Services Among Transgender People in the United States|journal=International Journal of Transgenderism|language=en|volume=16|issue=2|pages=68–79|doi=10.1080/15532739.2015.1064336|s2cid=5500532|issn=1553-2739}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== In the UK, non-binary individuals also experience health discrimination. A 2015 survey conducted by the Scottish Trans Alliance examined experiences of medical services among 224 non-binary individuals who had attended a gender identity clinic (GIC) in the preceding two years. When asked if they had experienced "problems getting the assistance they needed" because of their non-binary identity, 28% chose "yes", 28% "maybe", and 44% "no". Denial of treatment was reported by 13 respondents (6%), delay of treatment by 12 (5%), and lack of knowledge or understanding about their identities by 10 (5%). When asked if they had been pressured by the GIC, 43% chose "yes", 12% "unsure", and 46% "no". Respondents reported having been pressured to appear more binary (36 individuals, 17%), to change their names (19, 9%), to socially transition to fulfill the [[real-life experience (transgender)|real-life experience]] requirement (13, 6%), or to pursue medical transition (13, 6%).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scottishtrans.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Non-binary-GIC-mini-report.pdf|title=Non-binary people's experiences of using UK gender identity clinics}}</ref>
Under the law of the United Kingdom, individuals are considered by the state to be either male or female, the sex that is stated on their birth certificate. This means that non-binary gender is not recognized in UK law.
==Legal discrimination== {{distinguish|Legal recognition of non-binary gender}}
===United States=== Despite being more likely to achieve higher levels of education when compared to the general public,<ref name="transgenderlawcenter">{{Cite web|title = Non-Binary Identities & the Law|url=http://transgenderlawcenter.org/archives/10208|website = transgenderlawcenter.org|date=April 16, 2014|access-date=October 21, 2015}}</ref>{{rp|11}} 90% of non-binary individuals face discrimination, often in the form of harassment in the workplace. 19% percent of self-identifying non-binary individuals reported job loss as a result of their identities.<ref name="transgenderlawcenter"/> Anti-discrimination laws that prohibit discrimination specifically against non-binary individuals do not exist.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} However, [[Title VII]] and the current proposed version of the federal [[Employment Non-Discrimination Act]] use such terms as "gender identity" and "gender expression", categories under which non-binary individuals fall due to the fact that their [[gender expression]] cannot be defined as male or female.<ref name="transgenderlawcenter" />
In 2004, Jimmie Smith was terminated from the fire department in Salem, Ohio, after revealing their diagnosis with Gender Identity Disorder and intentions to undergo a male to female transition. The district court determined the reason for termination was because of their "transsexuality" and not their gender non-conformity. The case was appealed to the Sixth Circuit, which overturned that decision and clarified to courts that under Title VII, sex discrimination was to be considered broader than only the traditional assumptions of sex.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Reineck|first=Katie|date=2017|title=RUNNING FROM THE GENDER POLICE: RECONCEPTUALIZING GENDER TO ENSURE PROTECTION FOR NON-BINARY PEOPLE.|journal=Michigan Journal of Gender & Law|volume=24|pages=265–322|via=OmniFile Full Text Mega (H.W. Wilson)}}</ref>
Twelve states currently have legislation which bars discrimination based on gender identity.<ref>{{Cite web|title = State Laws That Prohibit Discrimination Against Transgender People - National Center for Lesbian Rights|url = http://www.nclrights.org/legal-help-resources/resource/state-laws-that-prohibit-discrimination-against-transgender-people/|website = www.nclrights.org|access-date = 2015-10-21|date = 2013-07-25}}</ref> Despite these efforts, non-binary individuals are subject to higher rates of physical and sexual assault and police harassment than those who identify as men or women, likely due to their gender expression or presentation.<ref name="Harrison2011"/><ref>{{Cite web|title = 10 Myths About Non-Binary People It's Time to Unlearn|url = http://everydayfeminism.com/2014/12/myths-non-binary-people/|website = Everyday Feminism|access-date = 2015-10-21|language = en-US|date = 2014-12-06}}</ref>
====Identity documents==== According to the Transgender Law Center, 70% of transgender people are not able to update their identity documents and one-third of have been harassed, assaulted or turned away when seeking basic services,<ref name=osf-2017>{{cite web |title=Gender Identity Recognition at the Border and Beyond |last1=Skeen |first1=Lisa |url=https://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/voices/gender-identity-recognition-border-and-beyond |date=April 5, 2017 |website=Open Society Foundations |access-date=October 26, 2017}}</ref> and one third are not able to update their documents post-transition.<ref name=hrc-2017>{{cite web |title=Understanding the Transgender Community |author=<!--staff writers, no byline--> |url=https://www.hrc.org/resources/understanding-the-transgender-community |website=Human Rights Campaign |access-date=October 26, 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, the U.S. State Department was sued for denying a passport to [[Dana Zzyym]], who is a veteran, an intersex person and then also identified as a non-binary person. Zzyym wrote "intersex" on their passport form instead of male or female, which were the only two available gender fields on the form. Zzyym was denied the passport, which led to LGBTQ advocacy organizations filing a lawsuit against the U.S. State Department on Zzyym's behalf. The advocacy group [[Lambda Legal]] argued for gender-neutral terms and a third option on U.S. passports, arguing that the existing passport fields violated the [[Due Process Clause]] and [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the U.S. Constitution. The State Department argued that adding additional gender fields to the passport form would prevent the agency's efforts to combat identity theft and passport fraud. The Tenth Circuit Court ruled in favor of Zzyym, the first time in U.S. history that the federal government recognized non-binary people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/intersex-dana-zzyym-passport-decision/|title=Judge rules in favor of intersex veteran who was denied passport|website=PBS NewsHour|date=November 23, 2016}}</ref>
California, the District of Columbia, New York City, New York State, Iowa, Vermont, Oregon and Washington State have currently removed the surgical requirement to complete a change on a birth certificate. In these states, to change the gender on a birth certificate, one must fill out a standardized form but legal or medical approvals are not required. In Washington, D.C., the applicant fills out the top half of the form and a health or social service professional must fill out the bottom half. A person may face obstacles obtaining a court order in order to make a change to documents in other states. Tennessee is the only state that has a specific statute that forbids altering the gender designation on a birth certificate due to gender surgery, while Idaho and Ohio have the same prohibition, but via court decision rather than by statute; and in Puerto Rico, a U.S. territory, a court ruled that gender markers could not be changed on identity documents under any circumstances.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lambdalegal.org/know-your-rights/article/trans-identity-document-faq|title=FAQ About Identity Documents|website=Lambda Legal}}</ref><ref name=lambda-state>{{cite web |title=Changing Birth Certificate Sex Designations: State-By-State Guidelines |author=<!--staff writers, no byline--> |url=https://www.lambdalegal.org/know-your-rights/article/trans-changing-birth-certificate-sex-designations |date=February 3, 2015 |website=Lambda Legal |access-date=October 26, 2017 }}</ref>
In California, the Gender Recognition Act of 2017 was introduced in the State Senate in Sacramento in January 2017 and signed into law by governor [[Jerry Brown]] on October 19. The law recognizes a [[third gender]] option known as "non-binary" which may be used on state-issued documents such as driver's licenses to more accurately reflect a person's gender. Senate bill SB179 was originally drafted by State Senators [[Toni Atkins]] and [[Scott Wiener]]. The law also makes it easier for existing documents to be changed, by removing requirements for sworn statements by physicians and replacing it with a sworn attestation by the person seeking to make the change to their documents. The Executive Director of Equality California commented, "It is up to an individual—not a judge or even a doctor—to define a person's gender identity."<ref name="Gutierrez-2017">{{cite web |title=Bill seeks 3rd gender option on licenses, birth certificates |last1=Gutierrez |first1=Melody |url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Calif-lawmakers-seek-nonbinary-gender-10886782.php |date=January 26, 2017 |website=SFGate |publisher=[[Hearst Communications|Hearst]] |access-date=October 26, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="Bowerman-2017">{{cite web |title=Female, male or non-binary: California legally recognizes a third gender on identification documents |last1=Bowerman |first1=Mary |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/10/19/female-male-non-binary-california-legally-recognizes-third-gender-identification-documents/779188001/ |date=January 26, 2017 |website=USA Today |publisher=[[Gannett]] |access-date=October 26, 2017 }}</ref>
The first two U.S. citizens to receive a court decreed non-binary gender were in Oregon and California. In [[Oregon]], [[Jamie Shupe]] was able to obtain a non-binary designation in June 2016 after a brief legal battle.<!--don't use a gender-neutral pronoun here: Shupe now identifies as male. See https://jamieshupe.wordpress.com/2019/01/26/public-announcement-i-have-returned-to-my-male-birth-sex/--><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.portlandmercury.com/images/blogimages/2016/06/15/1466024211-shupe_ruling.pdf|title=Case No.: 16CV13991: In The Matter Of The Sex Change Of Jamie Shupe, Petitioner|last=Holmes Hehn|first=Amy|date=June 10, 2016|work=Portland Mercury|access-date=November 30, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160626085558/https://www.portlandmercury.com/images/blogimages/2016/06/15/1466024211-shupe_ruling.pdf|archive-date=June 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/16/jamie-shupe-first-non-binary-person-oregon|title=Jamie Shupe becomes first legally non-binary person in the US|first=Lauren|last=Dake|date=June 16, 2016|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Following in Shupe's footsteps, [[California]] resident Sarah Kelly Keenan was also able to legally change her gender marker to non-binary in September 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/californian-becomes-second-us-citizen-granted-non-binary-gender-status-n654611|title=Californian becomes second US citizen granted 'non-binary' gender status|website=NBC News}}</ref> After both Shupe and Keenan had success with their cases, more people have been inspired to take on the legal battle of changing their gender to a non-binary marker. With the help of organizations such as the Nonbinary & Intersex Recognition Project dozens of these petitions have been granted and additional states have changed regulations to provide a third gender option on state ID, birth certificates, and/or court orders.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.intersexrecognition.org/resources|title=Resources|website=www.intersexrecognition.org|access-date=July 31, 2018}}</ref>
===United Kingdom===
Non-binary is not legally recognized as a gender identity in the United Kingdom. The [[Gender Recognition Act 2004]] allowed people to apply to the Gender Recognition Panel for a change of gender after living as the gender they wished to show on all their legal documents and being given a diagnosis of [[gender dysphoria]] by at least two health professionals. However, this only allowed for a legal change of gender from male to female or vice versa.
=== Canada === In 2002, the [[Northwest Territories]] was the first of [[Canada]]’s provinces to explicitly include gender identity as a protected group from discrimination under the law, followed by [[Manitoba]] in 2012.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cossman|first=Brenda|date=January 2018|title=Gender identity, gender pronouns, and freedom of expression: Bill C-16 and the traction of specious legal claims|journal=University of Toronto Law Journal|volume=68|issue=1|pages=37–79|doi=10.3138/utlj.2017-0073|s2cid=148916100|issn=0042-0220}}</ref> By 2015, every Canadian province and territory had included similar changes to their discrimination laws.
In 2017, Canada passed [[An Act to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act and the Criminal Code|Bill C-16]] which formally recognized non-binary gender people and granted them protection under the law towards discrimination on the grounds of "gender identity" and "gender expression."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/item/global-legal-monitor/2017-09-11/canada-senate-passes-landmark-transgender-rights-bill/|title=Canada: Senate Passes Landmark Transgender Rights Bill|website=Library of Congress}}</ref>
===Australia=== The Sex Discrimination Act of 1984 did not explicitly protect non-binary persons from discrimination until the Sex Discrimination Amendment (Sexual Orientation, Gender Identity and Intersex Status) Act of 2013, which prohibited any discrimination on the grounds of "gender identity" and "intersex status". This amendment also removed the use of "other" and "opposite sex" in exchange for broader terms like "different sex".<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Bennett|first=Theodore|date=2014|title='No man's land': Non-binary sex identification in Australian law and policy|url=http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/37-3-14.pdf|journal=University of New South Wales Law Journal|volume=37|pages=847–873}}</ref>
In 2014, the [[Australian High Court]] legally recognized non-binary as a category for people to identify with on legal documents. After [[Norrie May-Welby]] made a request for a third gender identity on legal documents and was eventually denied, Norrie chose to take the matter up with Australia's [[Human Rights Commission]] and their [[Court of Appeal]]. After a four-year long legal battle beginning in 2010, Norrie finally won the case. From this and the legalizing of the matter in [[New South Wales]], the [[Australian Capital Territory]] made the decision to pass a law that recognized non-binary identities. Several other states and territories followed suit afterward.
